lesson.title: REST API
lesson.summary: In this lesson, we will cover the development of REST APIL for a group of images, how to store data in DynamoDB and build a web app using React.

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A01 Intro To Lesson 2 - What Is In This Lesson
Lesson outline
atoms.text:
What we will cover
- Develop REST API for group of images.
- Store data in DynamoDB
- Build a web application using React framework to use our application.

atoms.title: What we will use
atoms.caption: We will use AWS Lambda, API Gateway and DynamoDB
atoms.alt: We will use AWS Lambda, API Gateway and DynamoDB

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A02 Rest API With Serverless (Slides)

atoms.text:
When implementing REST API with AWS Lambda our functions receive HTTP requests in the form of events. Each event contains information like HTTP method, HTTP body, headers, etc.

A Lambda function should process this event and return a response that will be converted by AWS into an HTTP response.

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A04 Amazon API Gateway (Slides)
Untitled
atoms.text:
**What is API Gateway**

- Entry point for API users
- Pass requests to other services
- Process incoming requests

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A03 API Gateway Integrations
API Gateway targets
atoms.text:
**API Gateway targets**

Possible targets for an HTTP request processed by API Gateway:

- Lambda Function - call a Lambda function
- HTTP Endpoint - call a public HTTP endpoint
- AWS Service - send a request to an AWS service
- Mock - return a response without calling a backend
- VPC Link - access resource in an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A05 Endpoint Types (Slides)
Endpoint types

question.prompt: What endpoint type in API Gateway directs all requests through a CloudFront distribution?

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A06 Lambda Integration Modules (Slides)
Lambda Integration Modes
atoms.text:
**Lambda integration modes**

- **Proxy** - passes all request information to a Lambda function. Easier to use.
- **Non-proxy** - allows to transform incoming request using __Velocity Template Language__

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A07 API Gateway Stages
Untitled
atoms.text:
API Gateway Stage is a logical reference to a lifecycle state of the REST API implementation.

You can read more about API Gateway stages in [AWS documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/set-up-stages.html).

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A14 Demo - Use API From A Web Application Part 3
ND9990 L02 A15 Why Can T We Make Any Requests- Cross-Origin Request Policy
Same-Origin policy
atoms.text:
Single-Origin request policy is enabled in all browsers by default and is an important security measure. To send requests from a web application to a different domain (e.g. from localhost to API Gateway domain) we need to configure Cross-Origin request policy in our API.

Alternatively, we need to configure our application so that JavaScript would be served from the same domain that is used for our REST API, but this goes beyond the scope of this course.

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A16 Demo - Enable CORS For The GET Method Parts 1, 2, 3
ND9990 L02 A17 Storing Data
AWS Databases Options
atoms.text:
# AWS databases

AWS provides a number of database options and it may be confusing when to use what solution.

You can find the full list of databases available on AWS [here](https://aws.amazon.com/products/databases/).

You can also watch this [webinar from AWS](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6K0Sds9Y2N0) that can help you to make the right choice.

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A18 DynamoDB Overview
More about DynamoDB
atoms.text:
# More about DynamoDB

DynamoDB is a NoSQL database. If you are not familiar with NoSQL databases, you can read more about it here: [Guide to NoSQL for Software Developers](https://brewing.codes/posts/nosql-guide/)

If you want to read a more detailed overview of DynamoDB, you can read this two part series: 

- [Should you use DynamoDB?](https://brewing.codes/posts/dynamodb-overview/)
- [Data modeling with DynamoDB](https://brewing.codes/posts/dynamo-data-modeling/)

atoms.title: DynamoDB concepts

complex_prompt.text: Match names of DynamoDB concepts with their definitions

correct_answer.text: A single stored record in DynamoDB
Similar to a cell in a table in a relational database

answers.text: Similar to a cell in a table in a relational database
A single stored record in DynamoDB

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A19 Partitions In DynamoDB
Selecting a partition

question.prompt: What part of an item is used to select a partition in DynamoDB

answers.text: Selecting a partition is a random process
Id and a timestamp of an item

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A20 DynamoDB Capacity Modes
DynamoDB Capacity Modes
atoms.text:
**DynamoDB Capacity Modes**

DynamoDB has two capacity modes:

- **Provisioned capacity** - we need to define the maximum amount of read/write requests DynamoDB can handle. The higher the limit we set, the more we have to pay per month. Requests are throttled if we go above the specified limit.
- **On-Demand** - DynamoDB will handle as many requests as we send, and we pay per-request. Can be more expensive comparing to Provisioned capacity, but is better for applications with unpredictable traffic patterns

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A21 DynamoDB With Node.Js (Slides)
Access DynamoDB
atoms.text:
Sample code to read data from DynamoDB:

```ts
const docClient = new AWS.DynamoDB.DocumentClient()
 ...
 const result = await docClient.scan({ // Call parameters
   TableName: "Users",
   Limit: 20
 }).promise()
```

Don't forget to call the `promise()` method to use the async/await feature.

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A22 Connect API To DynamoDB Demo Part 1
ND9990 L02 A23 Connect API To DynamoDB Demo Part 2
ND9990 L02 A24 Connect API To DynamoDB Demo Part 3
ND9990 L02 A25 Creating Items With DynamoDB
Benefits of using UUIDs
atoms.text:
In this course Lambda functions generate random UUIDs and use them as IDs of created items. They do not check if these UUIDs are unique, so you might be wondering, what would happen if two function calls generate the same ID? This is called a collision, and depending on how we configure a request it will either overwrite an existing item or will cause an error.

Fortunately the probability of this event is so [low](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#Collisions) that we can safely ignore it in practice. 
Because of this UUIDs are [commonly used as IDs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#As_database_keys) in databases.

ND9990 L02 A33 Preflight Response (Slides)
Preflight request
atoms.text: For certain HTTP methods a browser first sends a preflight request before an intended request. It is used to check if a server will process the request that a browser intends to send.

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A34 Process Preflight Response Parts 1, 2, 3

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A36 Implement Pagination
ND9990 L02 A37 Pagination With DynamoDB
DynamoDB Results Pagination
atoms.text:
# DynamoDB Pagination

You can read more about DynamoDB pagination [here](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/Scan.html#Scan.Pagination).

atoms.title: ND9990 L02 A38 Implement Pagination Demo Solution Part 1
Untitled
atoms.text:
## Starter Code
You can download the starter code here:  https://github.com/udacity/cloud-developer/tree/master/course-04/exercises/lesson-2/starter-code

## Implementation

In this exercise, you will have to write a Lambda function that implements pagination. This means that you will be able to get items from a REST API chunk by chunk instead of getting all values in one reply.

Notice that the value of the `LastEvaluatedKey` in a DynamoDB result is a JSON object. To pass it in another GET request we convert it to a string and then use URI encoding to allow to pass it in a URL:

```ts
encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(lastEvaluatedKey))
```

To pass a value coming in a GET request you would need to first decode a string and then parse a JSON string:

```ts
// Value read from a query parameter
const nextKeyStr = ...
// "exclusiveStartKey" can be passed a parameter to a "scan()" call
const exclusiveStartKey = JSON.parse(decodeURIComponent(nextKeyStr))
```


## How to build the project

For this exercise, you don't need to create a `.zip` package. Instead, you can just create a new AWS function and copy the code into the editor in AWS Lambda.

You would also need to set correct IAM permissions for a Lambda function to send metrics to AWS CloudWatch. You can copy an IAM policy from the `iam-policy.json` file in this project.

## Other resources

You would have to create two other AWS resources:

* A DynamoDB table
* API Gateway API

### DynamoDB table

To create a DynamoDB table, you need to create a table with the following parameters:

* Table name: `Groups`
* Primary partition key: `id (String)`
* (Optionally) Uncheck the `Use default settings` checkbox, and select `On-demand` in the `Read/write capacity mode` section

It is **important** that you name your table `Groups` if you want to use the IAM policy provided for this exercise.

You would have to add a few items to your table to test pagination. Here are some items that you can add to the table:

```json
{
    "id": "1",
    "name": "Dogs",
    "description": "Only dog images here!"
}

{
    "id": "2",
    "name": "Nature",
    "description": "What can be a better object for photography"
}

{
    "id": "3",
    "name": "Cities",
    "description": "Creative display of urban settings"
}

{
    "id": "4",
    "name": "Computers",
    "description": "For the techies among us"
}
```

### API Gateway API

You can follow the same process that we've used in the lesson to create an API Gateway API. You would need to:

* Create a new API
* Add a GET method for the `/groups` resource and use a Lambda function that you wrote in this exercise as a target for this method
* Deploy this new API

## Expected result

If you send a `GET` request using this URL: `https://{{apiId}}.execute-api.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/dev/groups?limit=2` you should get a reply like this:

```ts
{
    "items": [
      ...
    ],
    "nextKey": "%7B%22id%22%3A%221%22%7D"
}
```

Notice that you need to replace `{{apiId}}` with an id of the API that you've deployed.

If you pass the `nextKey` and use it with another `GET` request using this URL: `https://{{apiId}}.execute-api.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/dev/groups?limit=2&nextKey=%7B%22id%22%3A%221%22%7D`

```ts
{
    "items": [
      ...
    ],
    "nextKey": null
}
```

If `nextKey` is `null` it means that there are no more items to return.

ND9990 L02 A41 Summary - What We Have Covered
Summary and what's next
atoms.text:
## What we covered in this lesson
- Built a serverless REST API
- How to use API Gateway
- Basics of DynamoDB
- Additional topics: CORS/React  


## What is next? 
- Automate our deployment
- Use Serverless framework
- Continue developing our API
